newsitem.title: UK: North Sea Brent trades high, other grades softer.
newsitem.headline: North Sea Brent trades high, other grades softer.

text.p: North Sea Brent crude traded at a comparatively high level again on Wednesday as this week's main buyer came into the market again.
Other sweet grades showed their vulnerability to the reduced refining margins, holding at recent lower levels, traders said.
Outright IPE December Brent lost 48 cents by 1940 GMT to trade at $24.18 a barrel.
Brent intermonth spreads lost ground in line with Dec/Jan, which traded late on Tuesday at +68 cents, was offered late on Wednesday some 10 cents lower.
Oseberg - with a couple of October cargoes still unsold - traded twice on Wednesday - once at Dated Brent +42 cents for a November 10-12 cargo and again at Dated +25 cents for a Nov 5-7 loader.
Talk of an end October Ekofisk moving at a very low level could not be confirmed.
The trader who has bought some five Brent cargoes this week picked up one of Wednesday's cargoes (November 7-9) from the equity holder at November Brent +10 cents.
Some traders said this level was artifically high and not a true representation of the market.
"They can't justify these levels for refining when you look at the cost of Brent relative to alternative crudes," one refiner said.
In the Mediterranean Urals levels held steady in a balanced supply/demand situation, traders said.
Some three large cargoes and a handful of smaller vessels were on offer and the level was held around dated Brent -60/-55 cents. ---London Newsroom +44 71 542 8978
